President Obama is doing everything he can to work with republicans. These ideas are some that the GOP have said they would like. We need revenue for the government to keep funding valuable programs and we need to have people who can to pay more taxes do that.

Let's also add a minimum per capita tax for all households that earn beyond certain minimum family income ( that varies with size of households) There are currently rougly 50% of all US families that do not pay any income tax because of various refundable and nonrefundable tax credits.  The US may well be able to close the deficits significantly by requireing all households to pay at least $50 to $100 per person so long as their income exceed  certain percentage above the poverty level.

The author is correct; Americans don't know how much we agree with President Obama.

But we do know how much we disagree with him. And he'll soon find out in 2012.

bc

I agree with this accept the missing point, that I believe Americans expect that the President should have a clear and communicable plan to achieve long-term debt and deficit reduction first, so that when he communicates the desire to support the present economy with stimulus, job support, and spending, he appears to be responsible and thoughtful about the long-run goals.  I agree that the President has failed to craft a message that is simple and clear and failed to repeat it as often and relentlessly as is necessary to win the media dialogue.  This must be done in order to shape the debate.

The President is a piker with this jobs bill. It should be for 10 trillion - yes, 10T, and that sound you hear is the thud of Republicans across the nation falling over in a dead faint. But the cost of money is cheaper than it will ever be again in our lifetime, the need is huge and imagine putting 10-15 million people back to work over the next 5 years. After a brief period of disbelief accompanied by paying off remaining personal debt, spending would explode because I truly believe people WANT to buy things, want to treat themselves and others after an extended period of personal austerity. If Republicans refuse, fine. Spend what monies he CAN get through Congress only in the districts where the representative said "aye" to the spending bill in question. When people in one district wonder why their neighbors get what federal largesse there is, and they don't, let the recalcitrant reps explain it to their electorate.

Wonderful editorial. Hope you sent a copy of it to the Oval Office and the President's clueless and feckless advisors.

The whole country is disillusioned and full of false information. I cannot believe what some people tell me about the Republicans. I repeatedly hear: They say the GOP will create jobs. I ask how and they, of course, have no idea nor do the Congressional Republicans except Cut Taxes. The broken record (CD) has become so annoying.

You are so right about the Democrats losing their talking points. Can you have so many cowards in Congress? Well, yes and we do.

I have decided after swearing I would never vote for Obama again to support his candidacy. I resented that I gave so much to his last campaign but this time I am forewarned but willing to at least give it a chance. The alternative is unthinkable.

But at the same time I ask, where are the American protestors? Why aren't mobile old folks standing in front of the Capitol and White House with placards. Why are they not protesting both parties and the president. He so blithely offers to throw the old and sick under the bus. No thought of the consequences. Last week it was said he backed out of cutting Social Security and Medicare then Yesterday I read that he is offering this to the Republicans to cut. What!! The Media don't report well and ignore important stories and foolishly without question waste our time with endless reporting of useless details about the election in fourteen months. It is mindless because that much time is a lifetime in politics. How come we made an industry of our elections while other advanced countries can get it all done in six weeks?

Can Obama change his temperament? I don't know but doubt it. And I fear Mitt Romney will be our next president. At least he's the least scary of the loudmouth pack.

"The huge benefits of his health care reform, which Republicans have vowed to repeal, will become clearer to Americans in the years ahead." Here's the problem, the future is always with us and never here. He got played and he, and apparently you , don't get it. By the time this 'future' gets here, it will be the expected present.
This man is 'our' President. GM and Chrysler don't prove anything if the rest of the job market stinks. He saved a bunch of highly paid voters, while an economy, made up of mostly service sector employees, continues to spiral downward. Get real with all this. Stop trying to get people to buy into your pampered reality.

September 18, 2011

Man voters, and wannabe voters, know what they want, but not the party. It is right time for President Obama, to establish his leading a Progressive workers party, now.
For Obama to run on both a Democratic party leader, and in coalition with his United Progressive Workers Party, will happen the sooner the better for uniting people and not raging inertia by divisiveness.

May sound like more division, but Obama is a visionary and is profoundly adept on foreign relations; yes including the Ira, Afg / Pak theaters. Obama needs to come out to the starving populace, and get their campaign dollars and votes, for a obtaining an impressive re-election win in 2012 for a worthy two term president –
Together we can, again!

America needs a unifier and a winner: voters –yes we can in an Obama party land! Vote progressive and get a job.

Joseph Amato
Manhattan, N. Y.

I see this editorial and the comments so far (whether pro- or anti-Obama) as a reflection of the same thing. Obama's reluctance to get up on the chariot and ride to a victory well within his grasp. Why reluctance? Future historians will try to figure out why. I think it is his intense longing to be moderate as a black leader -to disprove that all blacks fighting injustice have a bomb in their hands. As if MLK hadn't demonstrated that decades ago. Obama wants to be admired, to be liked, to be lionized. I and overwhelming numbers of Americans have already given him their adulation and their votes. I wonder if he is hedging his bets now. Sometimes in order to lead you must be willing to be despised. Look at the abuse that Lincoln and FDR faced in leading a country threatened with destruction toward survival instead. Does Obama have the courage to fail for his ideals? I don't think so. And until he does, he WILL fail again and again.

The President may be conflict averse, but that is not the whole story.

Republicans present a united front and are very clever. They know how to manipulate people's minds and they know how to use the political energy that is released when they stir up people's fears and prejudices.

They did this most effectively during the debt debacle. It was almost like revisiting the Lewinsky years, when they attempted to destroy the President and the presidency, at great cost to the Nation. They tried to drain him until there was nothing left.

They basically failed with Clinton. Hopefully they will fail with President Obama.

It's taken the President too much time to get to this point, but it looks like he got his mojo back after his August vacation.

The President now needs to publicly confront the Republicans on their negative role in addressing this country's economic woes. But he needs a better jobs bill as the proposed measures alone are unlikely to have a significant impact on creating jobs in the short term for the newly unemployed.
Over the last decade small business have created the lion’s share of jobs in the USA while large firms have invested and created jobs abroad. It is time for the President’s advisors to suggest innovative ways to directly assist small businesses and unemployed individuals, particularly new graduates who want to start their own businesses and include these in the jobs bill . There are many proven examples of low cost , effective small business/entrepreneur support programs (loans and direct business support advice) and it should be simple to include some of these initiatives in the jobs bill and implement these with the cooperation of banks, local and state governments, universities and other private organizations.

It's tough to make the case that the stimulus was too small when the government still has $125 Billion dollars of the $840 Billion stimulus sitting around.  I think it's reasonable to ask our government to spend or give back the money that it has before granting the administration's request for more.

Mr. Obama has spent our money on giveaways to unions, Democratic congressional districts, states so they could pay more union workers, and 3% on virtually non-existent "shovel ready jobs" that he subsequently joked about. Now he's trying class warfare, trying to get the wealthy to pay more taxes on the money that they've already paid taxes on once. Is there any reason that a reasonable man would invest in this country and try to make a profit? Well GE doesn't think so, and the CEO of GE is heading up Obama's "Jobs Council," so what are the rest of us to think? GE has closed profitable US plants and moved them to China and elsewhere creating 25,000 new jobs--overseas.

Mr. Obama has also spent $500 million of your money on Solandra, a now-failed solar energy company when everyone in the solar industry (who didn't get money) knew that they were going to fail as their technology was to inefficient and too expensive. The Bush Administration refused a loan, and now email are coming out that the Obama White House was also warned about the overwhelming problems of Solandra--but Obama gave them the money anyway.

This editorial is about leadership, but the editorial staff at the New York Times is looking in all the wrong places, as is Obama, trying to delegate blame. The blame for this country's horrible economic plight rests directly on the donkey in the White House.

It's time for President Obama to take names and marginalize and trivialize his political opponents. There's plenty of footage showing John Boehner, Eric Cantor, and Mitch McConnell attenting President George W. Bush's budget-signing photo-ops which doubled the national debt. The same goes for the Bush tax cuts which added a pathetic one million private sector jobs over eight years. Furthermore, none of these Republican leaders had the courage and good conscience to put the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan on the books. The bottom line is that the Republicans have been terrible stewards of our national economy and debt.

The ultimate irony is that while Republicans deride the Obama stimulus package, they incomprehensibly have the audacity to attend ribbon-cutting ceremonies for projects in their districts funded by the stimulus package! Michelle Bachmann is one of them. The only thing missing is President Obama calling them on it.

Let's face it; the Republicans want President Obama to fail even if it means record unemployment and another recession. They invest in failure and are so desperate to get the White House back that they'll tank the economy.

I agree wholeheartedly. As a follow up, my question is WHY the organization, Organizing for America, has not done more to engage and support the President. A huge base was built with all the technology at their disposal from 2008 and very disappointing efforts barely took place. It is one of the biggest wastes of the 13M people who have talent, ideas and solutions. They could be the pipeline to push the discussion into the territory that this editorial has marked.

If OFA had the vision to engage and mobilize people, make us feel like we actually had a voice, President Obama would have an enormous surge of power behind him. His political capital would be an endless reserve.

The voice of the people is what is needed. This editorial is the first time that I've seen an effort to address and understand where the people stand. If our frustrations, opinions, and ideas were truly heard, utilizing the immense power that OFA has, we actually may be able to prevent a Do Nothing Congress from doing nothing. I go on to the site regularly to see if there's a hint of the fantastic tools that were available during the 2008 election. There's nothing. We're all sitting here dormant. I would be so very frustrated if I were the President. He's got a huge team ready to light up. But his team there appears to have no clue.

Once in a blue moon I get an Obama/OFA text to call my representative or watch an Obama vid. OR, they ask for their usual $5. But the fact that they missed the boat on ORGANIZING America is simply a tragedy. The most hilarious part of this story is that the technology is there to do so! I hope that this will change soon so that we could have the tools, canvas and ability to help the President by demonstrating how We the People can be heard, seen and activated. Maybe Obama needs to fire the staff there and bring in people who know true community organizing. We're ready.

As for the 8 out of 10 who agree to the Govt spending money, repairing Bridges, etc...I agree. That having been said, that was precisely what the First Stimulus plan was for. Remember the "shovel ready" projects & jobs? Never happened! Instead, the money was used for State and Local "bailouts", to Muni & State Unions. In short, the usual "payoffs" to the "friends" of this admin. The only Shovel involved, was the one the American people got mugged with.

I voted for President Obama, but I feel he needs to address the American people more often in Prime Time TV speeches to lay out his views to the nation. Richard Nixon used to say "this is the 32nd time I have addressed the nation." We need the 21st Century equivalent of FDR's fireside chat.

To the Republican mantra that "the stimulus didn't work", the President needs to repeat "that the tax cuts have not worked" (to create jobs).

When the Republicans say that "The New Deal did not get us out of the Depression, World War II did", the President needs to respond: "No, it was our RESPONSE to WWII that got us out of the Depression." And the Response was massive government spending.

Forget about addressing joint sessions of Congress, Mr. President. The Congressional Republicans are not listening at all. The other side of the aisle is not exactly composed of Everett Dirksens. Speak to Americans directly, Sir.

I think that Obama can be amiable, but firm toward Republicans.  I don't understand why his advisors are continuing down the bipartisan charade.  We need a President that stands up for most of the people against lobbyists, corporate and financial titans, and ideological zealots.  He can do this.  If his only goal is to pass legislation, then he will continue to be a small President with small ideas.  Think big! Let the GOP defend its gutting of the middle class safety net, its dumbing down of American discourse, and its indifference toward the American public's welfare.

I disagree with this article. Apparently you think it's OK to spend  trillions of taxpayer dollars on non-productive, non-democratic, non-sustainable government programs such as for-profit-wars, Wall Street bailouts, an out-of-control police/prison/security state, and bloated bureaucracies and taxpayer-paid salaries. As illustrated by these examples, the hallmarks of all government spending are waste, fraud, and corruption. The Constitutional role of government is not to act as a mafia, doling out tax dollars to politically favored programs, although this current paradigm is what is bringing down the economy.

The President's "plan" to cut spending is as absurd as Mao's "great leap forward" or Stalin's sundry 5 and 10 years plans.  Next year the federal government will spend more money than it receives in revenue, which will increase the debt.  The alleged "cuts", which are slated to occur after Obama has left office, are not actually reductions in the previous year's expenditures but reductions in the rate of increases in expenditures.  It's not particularly surprising that Obama has not proposed any real spending cuts, no President has for several decades (including Reagan who fake conservatives are quick to admire).  What's truly depressing, though predictable, is that the mainstream media is content to use the Obama press releases as its headlines, as if the budget will be cut and debt reduced.  Unless either the military, social security, or medicare are cut in actual terms, the debt will balloon until the debt is reduced with increased inflation.

Front and center to the debate regarding whether or not government spending should be cut is the notion that doing so at this time would be dangerous for the economy. Once again, failure to look at both sides of the equation leads to an erroneous conclusion.

If cutting government spending meant that overall spending was reduced that might be a problem, but money doesn't just disappear. If the government doesn't take as much money--either by taxes or borrowing--more money/purchasing power stays in people's pockets! People who will spend it (and maybe even save a little)!

The difference is that people making their own choices where to spend their money do a much better job of it than the government. Think of the legendary $500 hammers bought by the Defense Department. Or the Big Dig in Boston that was supposed to cost $2.6 billion and ended up costing almost $15 billion!

Of course, right now pundits like Paul Krugman are saying that the problem is people aren't spending enough so the government has to pick up the slack. Can you see why that argument makes no sense? First, any money the government spends has to be taken from consumers--either via taxes or inflation (anyone notice prices rising the last couple of years?)--eliminating an equal amount of purchasing power. Second, government employees actually do the spending, and history has shown that they're really not that good at their jobs. Once again, just think of the hammers.

If, on the other hand, we assume that individuals are only 5% more efficient at spending their money than the government, then even if individuals save 5% of any money the government doesn't spend--and spend the rest--the effect on the economy would be the same. [I used 5% because that is estimated to be the current savings rate in the United States.] If they are more than 5% more efficient (i.e., they can buy hammers for less than $475) then the economy is net-net better off, disregarding the increase in savings!! Since I'm pretty sure that individuals are better at buying hammers--or just about anything else--than the government, what's so scary?

Further, since individuals making rational purchase decisions can buy a lot more goods and services--goods and services that are produced and provided by people employed to do so--for the same amount of money as a government that spends too much on everything it buys, you can see why taking spending out off government's hands would actually increase employment! And why increased government spending has had the opposite effect!

So, instead of Americans spending (or saving) their money as they would like, the government takes it and spends it on the wages of government employees and overpriced goods and services. Is it any surprise this strategy hasn't worked for President Obama the first five times he's tried it? Or that government workers and unions say that spending cuts would be harmful? To them maybe, but not to anyone else. http://reasonablemannyc.blogspot.com
